text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today 
I'm going to show you how you can make your own

rice crackers at home now there are many different 
types of rice crackers out there and they vary

from culture to culture but today I'm going to 
show you two different ways the Thai people make

rice crackers now in Thai these are called Kao 
Tung and typically we serve them with dips or

sometimes you put a spread on it and serve them 
like snacks super versatile and really easy to

do let's get started so for this first type of 
rice crackers I am starting with jasmine rice

that I have cooked with too much water okay so I 
put about 50% more water than I normally would and

so it's kind of mushy and the key like this so 
they cling to each other more I am going to put

this rice on a Silpat or a silicone baking sheet 
that's nonstick if you don't have this parchment

paper will work just fine I'm going to cover this 
with saran wrap and now I am going to roll it out

into a thin sheet with a rolling pin and this 
is why you want to make the rice a bit mushy

because otherwise the grains won't stick together 
when you roll and some people if you want to make

the rice crackers super smooth they blend the rice 
completely until it's smooth and they just kind of

spread it onto the sheet you can do that as well 
but I like to do this because I like a little bit

of texture still in the crackers for me I like 
this to be about 1 to 2 millimeters thick that

looks good so at this point what I'm going to do 
is sort of redistribute odd edges so I'm using a

bench scraper here and I'm going to trim off any 
sort of like bulges and add that to parts that's

missing there you go that looks more or less 
rectangular and this it's kind of fun it's like

a puzzle game of some sort roll it back together 
now yes you can do this with brown rice if you're

going to do brown rice though I would suggest 
doing 5050 with white rice brown rice itself

is not a sticky and so you might have a hard time 
with getting the sheet to hold together depending

on how much you care about nice Edge's you can 
trim this off and now I'm going to just cut this

into squares now at this point you can use like 
a cookie cutter to punch out rounds if you want

to make it round or duck shape or whatever shape 
you want but I'm just going to go and make cuts

like that and it'll be easier if you wet this and 
it won't stick as much see it's a lot less sticky

if you wet the scraper alright so now we're going 
to let this dry off completely and you can do that

however you want in Thailand we usually let this 
sit out in the Sun but here I think seagulls will

probably come and eat it if I leave it outside 
so I just set it out in front of a fan and that

works really well or if you are in a hurry you can 
bake it in the oven on like a 200 degree very low

you don't want to brown this however after about 
a couple of hours of drying I'm going to flip all

this onto a rack so that they'll dry even faster 
and I'll show you how to do that when we get there

alright so these have now been drying for about a 
couple of hours and they have firmed up enough so

I'm going to flip them onto a rack and so what 
I do is I just put a rack right here ideally

it would be one rack but I only have two small 
ones put another tray on top and flip it over

up hopefully it all falls in the right place a 
and then I'm just going to peel this off so as

you can see my rack is quite wide and that's not 
ideal if you've got a finer rack you can actually

flip them right away because the problem is as 
you can see some of them are drooping over the

grill so I could have let this wait a little 
longer but I'm in a bit of a rush alright so

these will take at least one whole day to dry if 
you put it out in front of a fan like me you've

got a strong fan maybe a little shorter time but 
definitely not something you could serve today so

the second type of rice cracker we're going to 
make is more like a rice cake where the grains

are actually wholes or not mushing the rice and 
it's puffier it's lighter now I'm starting with

sticky rice for this because if we're not mushing 
their rice then regular rice doesn't hold on to

each other quite as well and you can make it with 
those it's just easier with sticky rice I find wet

my fingers a little so the sticky rice isn't sexy 
with my fingers and put it in a mold it doesn't

have to be round but that tends to be what we 
use and you can make it again a little thicker

a little thinner but I go on the thin side because 
they will puff up quite a bit if it's too thick it

doesn't it's not as light tada and just like the 
other one we're gonna let these dry so once your

rice crackers are dry this is what it looks like 
so this is the one we made just now exactly the

same but I made this yesterday and I let it dry 
overnight all right so it's quite thin now this

is another one I made earlier and I just wanted 
to show you because this one's a little too thick

for my liking but some people like it it's gonna 
fry up to be a little more substantial so if you

compare the two you can see that this one is much 
much thinner right and in our rice cakes of course

this is the one so it's dry and hard but you can 
still see that all the grains are intact and then

I also made one using black sticky rice so this 
is 30% black sticky rice I don't want to do all

black sticky rice because they're not that sticky 
and the color would be too dark so I mix this with

jasmine rice and it turns out beautifully purple 
these are what we would call raw rice crackers

you can throw the rice is cooked technically 
but to cook these two different ways you can

do it typically in Thailand we deep-fry them we 
always deep-fry them and that's the best way to

get them puffed up and and crunchy and light the 
other way because I know some of you're not going

to want to deep-fry is to broil them preheat the 
broiler really high and put these rice crackers

right underneath and it'll take a very short time 
and they'll burn quickly too so you have to watch

however that only works if your eyes crackers are 
quite thin with these thicker ones it will not

work okay the idea is to get the heat in there as 
quickly as possible so that they just go poof okay

if you bake these in the oven it will not work 
it'll be really dense really hard and eventually

they'll just burn okay I've tried it just so I can 
say it does not work alright so I'm going to try

these so I've got here's some oil you don't need 
a lot but your oil needs to be hot so I need this

to be at about 400 degree Fahrenheit and they 
actually don't end up being greasy at all if

the oil is hot enough as you can see they're just 
sort of like bloom open and it's pretty much done

as soon as they are open all right so here they 
are nice and fluffy and beautifully crunchy now

storage wise typically in Thailand we fry these 
at the time we're going to serve them or maybe a

day in advance because there's oil in it it does 
go rancid eventually and eventually they won't

be very crispy so I wouldn't make these and then 
put them in your cupboard however these raw ones

you can make them and keep them forever they will 
not go bad because it's completely dry so because

these rice crackers have a very neutral flavor 
they are great with any kind of dip that you like

hummus salsa guacamole baba ghanoush anything you 
want you can even eat them plain if you wanted to

they've got a slight sweetness nuttiness to them 
however if you want to serve this Thai style stay

tuned next week I'll show you a recipe of a dip 
that is a classic pairing with Cowtown all right

so when the video is up I'll put the link right 
here in this corner and also in the description

below and today though I'm going to show you 
how crunchy these are super crunchy there's a

bit of a grittiness to it and that's sort of 
characteristic of rice crackers it's actually

a slightly addictive just eating plain like this 
you know you think oh there's not much to it but

you just kind of keep going so I hope you give it 
a try and definitely stay tuned for next week dip

recipe and the recipe for this will be on a Thai 
kitchen calm when you make them some new photo on

Facebook Twitter or Instagram and I will see 
you next time for your next delicious time
